pros: Very detailed bosses, great interview process
cons: None that I know of

pros: Many employees are very competent, compassionate, dedicated to providing the best possible care to patients, and demonstrate strong work ethic.
cons: Upper level at Lahey has made such poor management decisions over the past year or so, trickling down the chain, that a large number of employees across the system from support staff, clinical, and MDs have left due to bad work environment. Every week, more are resigning. Vacant positions are not being filled; employees are expected to absorb the workloads of those who have left, with no compensation and minimal if any training. They are placing people in management positions who have no idea what they are doing. Understaffing, mismanagement, high stress, and delays in patient care are now the norm. Upper level is disconnected and uninterested in hearing from those doing the real work on what will help. BILH healthcare delivery system is in a state of chaos right now.

pros: Offers Competitive wage to employees.

pros: Great coworkers, good benefits if you use BILH locations
cons:
Leadership in behavioral health say they want to listen but every meeting where constructive solution oriented thoughts are offered they are met with defensiveness and occasionally outright derision. 

We are being asked to work short staffed and take on additional clients with fewer sessions even when weekly appointments are clinically suggested. We've been told again and again that they are hiring more staff, but it looks as though the recruiting team isn't doing enough- the low pay and job postings being up on every site for months is enough to keep candidates away. 

We've been asked to refer our friends. I'm sorry, I like my friends. Also when people DO refer their friends they have to track down HR and payroll and make sure they get their referral bonus. Oh that sign on bonus, you better keep track of both halves, because you might not get the second half on time.

The HR department is rude and unhelpful. I had to deal with them and recruitment when I moved from one dept to another and it was an ordeal. Also moving from one location to another is rare and made overly difficult. If you hope to move up, dream on. There is very little room for growth.

There is no formal training program for any location. My previous location had an amazing training program and daily staff meetings- even when we were WFH. Currently? Nah, we have BIWEEKLY staff meetings and people barely want to have those because they cut into productivity. Coworkers brought up the lack of connection and senior leadership blamed it on work from home and essentially said that was the trade off- you get work from home and you get lack of connection with your peers. The defensiveness and ridiculousness of senior leadership is just wild. 

WFH is not the problem, the company culture of not supporting your employees constantly expecting more and more and then belittling their concerns is the issue.

pros: peers and colleagues that work there
cons: hospital continues to grow and merge but administration doesn't

pros: This is an amazing place to work - like no company that I have ever seen.  Tremendously respectful and engaged Sr. Management Team - they really care, they are very smart, and they have a great deal of common sense.  Communication is excellent at all levels.  Processes and systems are well thought out and complete.  Where gaps are identified, staff are encouraged to provide input and their good suggestions are  supported and implemented.  I feel so proud to be a part of the organization, and would recommend it to people who are talented, bright, and want to bring their best to work every day.  We do important and meaningful work every day, and we have fun every day.
cons: Because it is so close to Boston Hospitals there is an expectation that salaries will be higher.  But as a community hospital some salaries are more conservative.  Not exactly a downside if you're looking at the whole package - benefits, opportunities to grow, and the chance to work with this great team are worth more than the difference in pay.  As in every work place there are a few unhappy people who've been there for a long time and don't know how good they have it at Winchester.  Appreciate all the good that is around you, or do us all a favor and work elsewhere.

pros: community feel, smaller than MGH

review_title: Way over their head with affiliation and growth goals.
pros: Professional and growing health system. Left before Joanne Conroy took charge, but hear good things about her.  Promote from within.
cons: No collaboration, even within department. Staff does not trust one another. Rude. Disorganized. Leadership thinks they compete with the teaching hospitals in Boston, but they don't. They really are so far away from the Boston hospitals in talent it's scary.

pros: Good benefits and exposure to executive leadership. Good opportunity to work with multiple stakeholders. If you can find other employees to conspire with you to gang-up on another employee or your boss then management will believe you.
cons: Highly political. Management makes unilateral decisions which they try to use policies to justify. Management date and marry each other. Two of the members of the management team dated each other and then got married. Neither lost their seat on the management team.

pros: Low level workers are all great people. Hospital gift shop is cute and cafe is big. Food good. Most managers/directors are great people.
cons: No communication, management doesn’t even get any communication from above. They swallow hospitals and force people out by treating them poorly. Taking away pay, changing employment terms at the drop of a hat. Not a work/Home balance conscious company. They don’t have hearts. Awful. Only worn here if you are desperate.

pros: Howard Grant the CEO has a great vision for the system. Decent compensation package. There is a lot to do in Burlington.
cons: Shared services had a lot of turnover. Most people were unhappy there leading to a negative environment and zero sense of team. Huge organizational problems. Antiquated systems (ex. time sheets for hourly), terrible technology, poor communication across departments and hospitals. Unaccommodating way of thinking.

cons: There was little autonomy and responsibility given to each employee, I felt like I was never given enough work to fill my time.
